course.name: Statics

reviews.comment_teaching:
âœ… Lambros is enthusiastic in teaching and sweated a lot after giving the lectures. He explained the content in a precise and clear way on the whiteboard. His lecture materials were quite spontaneous as he may ask the class to pick the numbers for his example randomly. He was willing to answer student's questions in details after the lectures. Sometimes his drawings were quite messy, and students were unable to see the numbers and details. So it would be a disadvantage sitting at the very back. Moreover, it is notable to note that Lambros demonstrate the questions at a quick pace. A mediocre student like me always found the lectures hard to follow.

reviews.author: chris310
reviews.title: Not that good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Mandatory course for civil students so no matter you like it or not, you have to take it :(
Module 1:Introduction, Vectors, Forces, Moments
Module 2:Statics of Particles (Forces in Plane and in Space)
Module 3:Statics of Rigid Bodies, equivalent systems of Forces
Module 4:Equilibrium of Rigid Bodies
Module 5:Distributed Forces: Centroid, Center of Gravity, Moments of Inertia
Module 6:Friction
Module 7:Analysis of Structures: Trusses (method of joints, method of sections)
Module 8:Analysis of Structures: Frames and Machines
Module 9:Axial Force, Shear Force, and Bending Moment Diagrams

basically, each module is useful and important for structure analysis. They seem easy when you are on the lecture but you will find that they so damn annoying for long calculation steps and complicated which make you always make mistakes easily.
reviews.comment_teaching: To be fair, I will say Lambros is quite enthusiastic about his teaching. I can feel that he is really trying his best to make everything clear in his lecture but I think most of the students don't really like his way of teaching and he always tried to make sure that we are all listening to his online lecture like polling, asking us to reply in the chatroom, taking attendance in lecture, forcing us to open the camera, etc. And most importantly, HE ONLY GAVE US HIS WRITTEN NOTES AFRER LECTURE AND HIS HANDWRITING AND GRAPH ARE PRETTY AWFUL. it is pretty hard to follow him in the online lecture and he will always blame us first.
reviews.comment_grading:
we only have 5 assignments, midterm, and final exam. but Lambros is pretty sick. For each unexcused absence, your overall mark will be reduced by 5%. For example, the total score of a student who missed four lectures will be subjected to a 20% reduction. Yes. deducting 5% of overall marks.
midterm: 42/100 with an average of 33 and a standard deviation of 16.5
final: unknown
HW: unknown
and I got C+ :(
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to attend all lectures and make sure on time and need to open the camera and answering every polling. Otherwise, TAs may see you as absent too :( it is quite chur for me. Lambros would ask you to watch his Coursera video before each lecture but I have never done so. Those videos are quite useful and clear in fact, sometimes they may clearer than his lecture.

For the assignment, they are actually not difficult but always require long calculation steps. Usually, it took me 3-4 hours for doing, checking steps, and checking answers for each arm. (you can find answer of asm from chegg and source)

reviews.author: Johnny Fung
reviews.title: Quite tough mechanics course
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite broad.
1. Newton's Laws
2. Vector and its applications
3. Trusses
4. Internal force diagrams
5. 1st and 2nd Moments of area
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching by professor iss quite fast that you need to keep studying even outside the lessons so that you can fully understand what the slides are talking about.
And most people study this course in Fall and there are about 12 students in my class and the professor also always ask if we have any problems then he will explain it to us again.
But for the tutorial, the examples used in the tutorial notes is really far from the lecture note ones. They are much more difficult than what professor teaches and it is normal if you can't understand those examples. Don't be frightened as the exams are not in the difficulty of tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading: I am not so sure in the grading as there are too few people. But if you get homework mostly correct and exams doing not bad I think that can have a b range or above.
reviews.comment_workload:
For the workload I think is about average. There are 4 homework and each needs you 4-5 hours to deal with. There are also in-class quizzes but this is just a small bonus adding on homework part just if your homework don't do well.
There are both midterm and final exams and if you fully understands the lecture notes examples I think that's enough.

Lambros would sometimes solve problems using short-cut methods created by himself, which were quite different from those in the textbook.

reviews.comment_workload: Quite reasonable but without some really practical exercise. Homework is way more easier than exam which makes me feel worried.

reviews.author: Civiljj
reviews.title: A course of mystery
reviews.comment_content:
Content of course is easy to understand because it is the foundation for statics.
Part of the content of the course:
-Vector (double and triple product)
-Moment (couple and equilibrium system and magnitude of moment at different axis)
-Different kinds of supports
-Centre of mass of a system and centroid
-Internal forces of members in a system
-Shear, axial and moment diagram

Basically most of them are on calculations. I think it is important to understand the concepts and then most of the questions would not be difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The powerpoint uploaded on canvas doesn't help much. It is important to go to lectures and jot down the things written on the whiteboard by Prof. Lambros. The pace of teaching is quite good at the first half of the course, professor would repeat a concept for several times so it is easy to catch. However, after the mid term the teaching speed was relatively much faster. So more attention should be paid in class, if you miss one sentence, you may be lost for the whole lesson.
But the teaching is quite good and numbers of examples were used to illustrate the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mark for final exam and assignments were not released.
I left a whole question blank for the final exam and were uncertain on the rest. Handed in all assignment and should have obtained full mark for that.
Mid term mark is 2 marks above mean and my overall grade is C+.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload indeed. If you understand the concepts in class, you don't even have to spend time for revision. 5 assignments in total, the first 4 is easy to handle. But the last one required the drawing of graphs so I spent some time on that. Attendance is taken during lectures so you must go to class.

reviews.author: I Want 1st Hon!
reviews.title: Way more interesting than CC courses!
reviews.comment_content:
Real 1st CIVL course! Interesting and addicting...
Course/Tutorial style: PPT+blackboard

My advice for those who wants to take this course in Spring:
If you are not a fast learner/wanna learn earlier/already decide CIVL/CIEV as your major, you can register this course in Spring! (Usually year 1, but you have to wait to register until the add-drop period starts! i.e. few days before lecture 1)

Class Schedule:
Learning & Intro.:
L1 (You will learn how to learn :) and think like an engineer!)
Foundation Part:
L2-5: Vectors, Force & Moment & **Free Body Diagram (PHYS1112+MATH1014 Vectors+CIVL1100 Little Structural Part) (Kinda review, but it is utmost important)
L6-L11. Equivalent Systems & Rigid bodies equilibrium in 2D & 3D; **Stable/improper/mechanism supports; Simple Beams; 2-force system & 3-force system (Still easy! but still important!)

Important Topics:
L12-15 **Truss: Method of Joints/Sections; ***Distributed Forces
L16-20 Frames & ***Diagrams (N, V, M diagram); *Centroids and Centers of Gravity; L21-24 **(1st/2nd) Moments of Inertia (Ixx, Iyy, Ixy) & Parallel Axis Theorem & Pappus Guldin Theorem & Mohr's Circle (A pair of compass is required to draw this!)

Midterm: L1-15 (1.5 hours)
Q1 Vectors, Force & Moment
Q2 Stable & Statically Determinism & Reaction & Supports
Q3 Truss: Zero force members & Method of sections & joints

Final: L1-24 (except Truss & Vector) (3 hours)
Q1 Simple supported Beams & Diagrams
Q2 Stable and statically determinism & Frame structure (with a bar & joint, i.e. 3 corners) & Diagrams
Q3 No real value (In terms of Alphabets) Frame Structure (with two corners) & Diagrams & ***Distance for maximum M to be minimal (Not from notes, but requires clever understanding)
Q4 Centroid, Moment of Inertia, Parallel Axis Theorem, Principal Axes & Principal moments of Inertia. (Optional: Can use Mohr's Circle as an approach)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ilias (Elias) (Professor in Spring Semester):
Only 19 students registered in this semester. No need to follow the UST grading scheme!
Only 8-12 students attend lectures...Some even doesn't appear in exams...
1 student from Pure Maths; 1 student from IE; 4 students from Year 1; ~2 students from ME...~3 students from CIVL and others I don't know!

He teaches slowly but efficiently! While you may not see clearly to the blackboard since the markers are not deep enough in colour...
He also uploads powerpoint right before lectures!

He frequently answers your email! ASK if you have problem! I am very glad that he said our class is the best class he has taught! :)

Lambros (Substitute Teacher for L20-21):
He teaches so fast and finishes one complex frame problem by mental calculation within 15 minutes, maybe 12 minutes?...HOW?

He has better accent than Ilias, but, actually, it does not matter!!!! I understand both of their English! TWO different teaching styles! I think both DO benefit to students with different abilities!

My advice for those who wants to take this course in Spring:
If you are not a fast learner/wanna learn earlier/already decide CIVL/CIEV as your major, you can register this course in Spring! (Usually year 1, but you have to wait to register until the add-drop period starts! i.e. few days before lecture 1)

TA is great, only 4-7 students attend the tutorials though... I didn't take all tutorials because of the time conflict to do something else. He answers all your questions clearly and sometimes tests/tricks you to make sure you FULLY understand!
reviews.comment_grading:
5 HWs & 5 Quizzes (Bonus to get possibly full mark in HW, take average with HWs): 15%
15/15 (Actually I get one mark deducted over 60 marks in one of the assignments & 1 mark deducted in one of the quizzes, so...still 15)

Midterm (35%): 71/100 Highest: 96; Most people got 65-75 (Not enough time...)
Final (50%): 75/100 Mean: 60.2 SD: 24.5
Highest: 90; 5 students got 82-90, and I am the sixth out of 19 students
(Challenging, but exam time is reasonable, though I haven't finished all...Prof.Ilias promised 75% diagrams in final and he kept his word :))

Final Grade: B+,
The first five students got A range...T^T
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair Workload!
When you are doing a HW with 5-9 problems, each problem takes you 45-60 minutes in average (without making careless mistake).
Once, you draw/write unclearly and copy incorrectly in your steps, you go through all the steps...

It takes 3-7 hours normally for each HWs...However, some are exam problems, so you can understand the question types in exams! But still, overall, you don't have group project, no essay, no lab reports....quite fair for all workload for HWs.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lambros has good teaching, He will give us many examples to help us better understand different structures. However, sometimes he will make mistakes with numbers or signs which will make his teaching a bit confusing. Prof Lambros will upload all lecture videos on canvas to help us better understand the knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme 1:
Assignment+Quiz: 20%
Mid-term Exam: 30%
Final Exam: 50%
Grading Scheme 2:
Assignment+Quiz: 20%
Mid-term Exam: 0%
Final Exam: 80%
Prof Lambros provide us with 2 grading schemes because we perform so badly in the Mid-term exam. Therefore don't give up if you get an unsatisfied result in mid-term, you still get a chance to achieve a good grade in this course. I perform so well in the mid-term exam but I forgot to do revision for the topic of question 2 of the final exam that I skipped the whole question 2. I thought I will only be able to get a B+ but turns out I get an A-. So I think the grading is ok. Attendance will not be taken every lesson, but Prof Lambros will randomly pick 2 days for quizzes. The quizzes will not be graded but will be taken as a reference for your attendance. Although we do now know the exact weighting of the quizzes, Prof. Lambros said it takes quite a heavy weighting.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy I think. The questions on the assignments are even more challenging than what will be examined in the final exam. So many topics are needed to study for the exam. If you want to keep yourself on track with Prof. Lambros's teaching schedule, you need to make sure you watch every lecture video required on canvas before each lecture and attend every tutorial class to have a better understanding of each topic and learn some skills for handling challenging questions.

reviews.author: UncleT
reviews.comment_content:
This course is equivalent to the course â€œMastering Staticsâ€ in Coursera, so Iâ€™ll list the topics as that in Coursera.

Topics:
1. Understanding Forces and Moments (vector, moment)
2. Equivalent Systems of Forces and Equilibrium (reactions of different supports, free body diagram)
3. Stability and Static Determinacy (analyze stability from static and kinematic perspectives)
4. Trusses (method of joints, method of sections, computer analysis)
5. Area properties and Moments of Inertia (centroid, distributed loading, moment of inertia, parallel axis theorem, Mohrâ€™s circle)
6. Internal Force Diagrams (axial, shear and bending moment diagrams)
7. Static Analysis of a Structure (combine all previous topics)

This course isnâ€™t difficult as it only requires basic knowledge of calculus and physics. Drawing bending moment diagram may be the hardest thing in this course. Remember BENDING MOMENT DIAGRAM is always drawn on the TENSION side!!!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lambros adopted â€œblended learningâ€ mode this semester. Students are supposed to watch the online videos (which are from Coursera btw) before they attend lectures, but I doubt not many have watched them. One thing I feel confused is Lambros will repeat what he says in the videos when conducting lectures, so I guess it isn't necessary to watch the videos?

Nevertheless, I enjoy Lambrosâ€™ teaching as he explains things quite clearly and always asks students questions. (TIP: To avoid being asked, donâ€™t sit in the back row.) The progress of this course is quite slow so I think itâ€™s easy to catch up even you donâ€™t understand at first glance. Overall, I appreciate Lambroâ€™s effort to let every student understand what is going on.

I can't say much about the TAs as I skipped most of the tutorials. (The slides are available on Canvas within a week after the tutorial.)

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: A good start of structural mechanics with relatively small class size
reviews.comment_content:
Statics, symbolizes the start of the structural series courses of civil engineering. This is the very first course of structural mechanics and it covers a quite in-depth content and concepts discussing the essence of the course.

The course covers several basic ideas of structural mechanics,

Vectors and its applications, moment of couple, equivalent systems, 2 force and 3 force systems are the main topics of first three weeks lectures. They are the basics and probably students with some basic understanding of vectors should find less difficulty digesting the lecture content.

The following few weeks covers equilibrium of rigid body in 2D and 3D, as well as defining the stability,properties of determinate and indeterminate structures. The idea of different types of supports were also addressed.

Trusses would be introduced in 2 weeks time and the focus would be finding 0 force members and using the method of joint and method of section in order to find the internal forces between members.

After mid-term, the key is learning how to draw the internal force diagrams of beams and complex structures, first introducing the idea of internal force, including axial force, shear force and bending moment. The key is understanding the calculus between different diagrams and the techniques of finding out the internal force in different parts of structure when external force and moments appear, as well as to know how to draw the diagrams precisely using lines and curves.

Finally, centroid ,center of mass,moment of inertia, parallel-axis theorem and mohr circle would be covered to find the I value of different structures and the change of I value when coordinates systems change.

The topics included are very essential for continuing the study of structural mechanics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Ilias is a Greek with some "Gleek" accent, but this is not a really serious matter for him to deliver the lecture content logically. He addresses the lecture content by reviewing the previous concepts learnt and proving the concepts needed in different topics, followed by demonstrating the examples to show the logic needed to solve the structural problems. He is not that kind of person just delivering the concepts mathematically and verbally, instead, he tried to deliver the concepts in an objectified manner, by randomly picking up objects in the classroom like door, tables, chairs and boxes to deliver the ideas.


With a relatively small class size(probably only 13 BOYS enrolled into the course and at most 10 BOYS attended lectures), Ilias tried to adjust the difficulty of the course content and focus more on whether students did understand the concepts well. If students had difficulties understanding, he waswilling to explain the concepts in a different way and emphazised the key again.


For tutorials, Ilias' phD student was in charge and provided some sort of reviews of the lecture content with further examples explained.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Assignments *4
35% Mid Term (1hr 20 mins)
50% Final (3 hrs)
some random quizzes treated as bonus

The assignments were a bit demanding with calculations involved, but most students scored over 90 for each assignment. The assignments were slightly difficult than the exam questions.

The exams I would say not really difficult if you really work hard understanding the concepts and finishing the assignments hand by hand. The only problem is the exam duration were very limited even only with 4 LQs with some clumsy steps. Probably the overall difficulty of Ilias' exams, compared to the past papers prepared by Lambros, was much less demanding.

Probably Ilias didn't follow the UG grade distribution due to the very small class size, I think he is quite generous giving out the grades if you really try your best,  it's not difficult to get a good grade since some students are just REPEATERS/ NON-CIVL students.

If you are a Year 1 student with PHYS 1112 getting a satisfactory grade, decided to get a CIVL major, willing to complete major requirements in an accelerated way and just because want to get better grades compared to students studying later, just enroll into this course with no doubt.

Grade B+
reviews.comment_workload: Just a bit heavy clarifying the concepts and finishing the assignment problems, probably need a lot of time. Reviewing the lecture content and worked examples, complete the past papers (Lambros' one) if you have sources and time.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.title: Stay Awake in Class.
reviews.comment_content:
In the beginning of the course, the lecturer introduced basic mathematics knowledge, such as sine law, cosine law, vectors, etc. Then, he started to introduce some basic physics knowledge in statics, including:
- Moment
- Equivalent Systems
- Systems at Equilibrium
- Equilibrium of a Rigid Body (2D, 3D)
- Beams, Trusses
- Method of Joints, Method of Sections
- Centroids (centre of gravity, distributed load --> concentrated load)
- Moments of Inertia
- Mohrâ€™s Circle
- Computer Software: Inputs
- Axial Force, Shear Force, Bending Moment Diagrams
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lambros is a passionate professor, willing to answer students' questions after the lecture. His ascent may cause misunderstanding in some words at the beginning, yet you can get used to it soon.
His words written on the whiteboard were always too small for those sitting at the back, and he promised to ask students at the back questions, so you had better come to the lecture hall earlier.

In addition, quizzes in class were often tricky as they were always related to the fundamental concepts or required conditions for some theorems. Therefore, they can be helpful for you to cope with his challenging exams.


There is a reminder that the bending moment diagram must be inverted vertically in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is ambiguous.

Originally,
Attendance + Assignments: 15%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 50%

However, probably owing to our poor performance in the midterm exam, the professor announced an amendment in the grading scheme, lowering the weights of midterm exam which we did not know what the finalised scheme was.

Plus, individual assignment score was not released despite the provision of solution.

Here is the only thing I know:
Midterm 73/100, mean 45.2, s.d. 14.8
Grade A
(I think I did not perform well in the final exam in spite of an extra time of 15 minutes)
reviews.comment_workload:
The quantity of assignments is light for me, though I often spent 2-3 hours on each.

Tutorial classes were made compulsory after the midterm exam. Attendance record was made by simply ticking your name or taking a written-quiz in class.

reviews.author: CyrusL
reviews.comment_content:
- Introduction, Vectors, Forces, Moments
- Statics of Particles
- Statics of Rigid Bodies, Equivalent Systems of Forces
- Equilibrium of Rigid Bodies, Stability of Rigid Bodies
- Centroid
---- MIDTERM ----
- Moments of Inertia, Mohr's Circle
- Analysis of Trusses: Method of Joints, Method of Sections, Computer Analysis
- Axial Force, Shear Force and Bending Moment Diagrams
---- FINAL EXAM ----

Most of the knowledge taught in the first half of the course overlap with secondary school physics as well as M2, and are thus relatively easy to master.

Computer analysis of trusses was once again examined in the final exam. Do not gloss over it.

The most important (and difficult) topic is axial force/shear force/bending moment diagrams: around half of the final exam was based on it, so make sure you understand how to draw them!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lambros clearly illustrates all the concepts (without boredom) and is more than happy to stay after class to answer questions. You really should pay attention to class, as the knowledge learned in this course are extremely important to future courses.

Make sure you take notes, as there are very few lecture slides posted on Canvas, which do not cover all content taught in class.

The tutorials are also great at explaining things; however, you may find them somewhat boring if you already understand most of the concepts. Complete tutorial slides are released at the end of each tutorial session.
reviews.comment_grading:
ORIGINAL SCHEME
Assignments + Quizzes: 15%
Midterm: 35%
Final Exam: 50%

In each lecture, there is a very short quiz for attendance-taking purposes. Missing even a single one of these will result in 5% deduction to your overall score, but why would you want to skip class anyways?

The midterm covers the first half of the course, while the final exam covers the second half. You will be quite hard-pressed to complete all questions in time for both exams.

Due to poor class performance in the midterm, the weighting of the final exam was increased while that of the midterm was decreased, according to the professor. By how much? I don't know.

MY RESULTS
Assignments + Quizzes: Unknown, estimated 80%
Midterm: 55/100 (Mean: 45.0, S.D.: 14.8)
Final Exam: Unknown, estimated 90%
Grade: A

Unfortunately, the grading was very opaque.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in this course comprises of 5 assignments. The first 4 can be completed within 2-3 hours, but the final one will take you significantly more time since it is about axial force/shear force/bending moment diagrams.

reviews.author: JoanneC
reviews.title: Best Prof.
reviews.comment_content: Actually, the contents are complicated,  calculation with a multitude of steps. Possessing good foundation in calculus will be a benefit for you. In addition, no lecture notes will be given, but notes written during class and tutorial notes are incredibly useful.
reviews.comment_teaching: Best Professor and TAs in the world!! Prof. KATAFYGIOTIS cared the students,  he ensured all students can follow and understand the concepts. He always encouraged us by saying "You are learning the best statics course in the world." in which I appreciated his passion in teaching and inspiring the youth.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good grade. I got above mean and gained A range
reviews.comment_workload:
5 assignments, difficult to finish it, but you are recommended to try to complete by yourself first and check the answer with your friends and sources. If you have any enquiry, please contact the TAs, they are always willing to answer our questions with precise explanation.
1 midterm and 1 final, if you attend all the class, do all the tutorial notes again, and revise all the lecture notes copied during class, most importantly, clarify all your doubts with TAs and Prof, you will definitely obtain a good grade. Hard work is certainly required. Moreover, Attendance needs to be recorded.

A little reminder: please sit in the front, because Prof. will write and talk in a fast pace. Sitting in the front can concentrate  and see clearly.

reviews.comment_content:
You must attend this course. It is NOT because of so-called "taking attendance". It's because all the important things are only mentioned in the class, not in the ppt/ tutorial notes/ YouTube videos(e.g." Dr Structure").

[[(More useful )class and excercise>tutorial notes>ppt from ESU sources>Dr. Structure(Less useful)]]

1)Introduction, Vectors, Forces, Moments
2)Statics of Particles (Forces in Plane and in Space)
3)Statics of Rigid Bodies, equivalent systems of Forces
4)Equilibrium of Rigid Bodies
5)Distributed Forces: Centroid, Center of Gravity, Moments of Inertia
6)Friction
7)Analysis of Structures: Trusses (Method of Joints, Method of Sections)
8)Analysis of Structures: Frames and Machines
9)Axial Force, Shear Force, and Bending Moment Diagrams

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lambro is enthusiastic in teaching, willing to solve any question you asked(including some easy questions that might be just mentioned a few minutes ago)
His teaching is over average, comparing to other professors
There is a Coursera course delivered by him that you can register. Therefore, if you are not clear about any concept, go and watch the videos and try the exercise there.

BUT

The teaching materials are not well-organised, a little bit messy.
No extra exercise will be provided besides those assignments. ( so go find some on Coursera)
You should NOT MISS ANY LECTURES otherwise, you got a penalty. (5%of the final marks per lecture you missed, no exceptions, for this year)
He always repeat himself, so every time, half of the lectures are wasted to review on the last lecture...

Tutorial:
Worth attending. You can do more practices and maybe some skills in solving questions.   

Overall, teaching skill is not bad but the course is not well organised. I will suggest you pay attention in class if you are an average student like me.
reviews.comment_grading: I really don't know why I got B+, better than my expectation. My midterm is only 3X/100, slightly above the mean. (Ya, the mean is only 3X/100...) All assignments grade and final grade are not transparent so I don't know my performance in homework and final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Chegg can help you get full marks in assignments( it's true also for other courses) but I strongly don't suggest using it. You can learn from your assignments. To be honest, assignments are easy but annoying, long calculations are required. I spent around 3hours per assignment, including checking steps, corrections... (and playing games, watching youTube...).

The workload is not high but remember to attend all the lectures and answer questions in class!!!!!!!

reviews.author: harrywn999
reviews.title: Best professor I found in ust
reviews.comment_content:
The foundation course for analyzing the structure.
It study some force, statics, truss structure. You have to understand all the concepts and contents in this course because later on in other course it is some of the fundamental part.

The detail content other people have posted already.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lambros does not rely on the textbooks or the PowerPoint. All the note are written on the board step-by-step which I think it is good and I can learn efficiently as long as I go to the lecture. The presentation is very nice and clear. I think it is not necessary to copy all the notes, it is more important to understand the steps. Once you understand, you will know how to do the question. If you want the recap, just refer to the tutorial notes.

Lambros has his accent and took me some time to get comfortable with. Other than that, he is a super passionate professor, he is willing to answer the questions. He want to make sure everyone in the class can catch up to learn together.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think everyone can get good grade as long as you attend the lecture and enjoy the way that lambros present the knowledge. Although the grading system is not transparent, but as long as you learn and try hard, your grade will not be bad. Lambros want everyone get good grade.

My mid-term is done poorly which below 1sd from the mean. I don't know about my final exam result but I tried my best.
At the end I got B+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair. 6 assignments. Each of them takes time and effort to finish it. Every assignment is related to the material covered in class, the difficulty is similar to the exam (some are even much harder). If you understand how to do all the questions in the assignment without copying from the source, I am sure you can do well in the exams. I personally suggest you to do revision before the assignment so it can be an assessment on how well you understand the topic.

reviews.author: Starliford
reviews.title: Statics
reviews.comment_content:
I group the content according to the lectures:
1. Newton's law, scalar and vector, free body diagram, law of sine and cosine, vector in 2D and 3D spaces
2. dot and cross products
3. different kinds of support (roller, hinge and fixed), equilibrium
4. centroids
5. moment of inertia
6. truss (method of joints and sections)
7. diagrams( axial, shear, moment diagrams)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I thought Lambros is drunk during the first few lessons because I could not even catch what he is talking about. I have almost a month of lesson before I can understand his lesson. When he is teaching "stupid" topic (I think he thinks that those are stupid), he is like not paying attention to what he is talking and no one can understand him. This all change when he go to part talking about centroid and the rest of the course which the content starts getting difficult. At that time he talked detailedly and organized to make everyone of us impressed and change our mind of having a nonsense professor all the time.
One thing that worth mentioning about this course is that he will do quizzes every single lectures (although he got bored at the end and skip some quizzes). It required you to be on time and sit for the whole lecture because you don't know when the quiz will start.
The quiz is only for attendance so no study is needed.

But at least in the end, everyone loves him <3.
Lambros hurray~~~~
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading of this course is quite unclear and "flexible".
The mid term is super hard and the mean is only 45, with 50%of the question asking about is this structure is in equilibrium or not.
The final score has never been published, and I only received my grade on 8th Jan which most of us are having industrial training.
He said that if you done well in the exam, we will get an A no matter how shit our mid term exam was.
He did what he said but still I rarely heard someone get an A at the end.
reviews.comment_workload: The homework is quite hard and laborious if you do not have any sources. Each homework takes you at least 2 hours to finish and usually you need to write at least four pages. I recommend that you should go through all the tutorial taught before you even start your homework unless you have already studied a similar course that have taught you similar stuff. The way of working a problem that the  professor taught during class is usually tedious and include a lot of fundamental element which can be skipped and ignored and you need some time to figure out a way to go around all these complicated process.

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: A key and fundamental course to all students with Civil as major
reviews.comment_content:
The course scope is , indeed a bit much and rush under prof Lambros teaching,the course contents are the following,
1.Introduction to Mechanics, Vectors, Forces, Moments(use of sine and cosine law)
2. Statics of Particles
3. Scalar Product: properties & applications
4. Vector Product: properties & applications
5. Mixed Triple Product
6. Moment of a Couple(use of the Cross Product)
7. Equivalent Systems, Systems at Equilibrium
8. Equilibrium of a Rigid Body in 2D
9. Properly supported Structures, Stable Structures in 2D, Simple Beams
10. 2-force System, 3-force System
11. Equilibrium of a Rigid Body in 3D
12. Trusses, The Method of Joints
13. Trusses, The method of Sections
14. Distributed Forces: Centroids and Centers of Gravity(Use of Direct Integration)
15. Moments of Inertia(use of Parallel Axis Thm)
16. Moments of Inertia, Mohrâ€™s Circle
**17. Axial Force, Shear Force and Bending Moment Diagrams(â€¼ï¸important topic,accounts for 40-45% of Final exam )
That's all about this course's content,as u can see,it is a bit much
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall, I can conclude prof Lambros lecture with only one word: AWFULğŸ¶

It is because Prof Lambros made his lecture mandatory but his lecture notes were pointless that made students hard to follow. Worse still, he doesn't have any well-written or organised lecture notes(PowerPoint or Pdf)for students to revise before the exam. So,many students didn't made enough preparations and practice in the run-up to the exam .As a result ,the exam results were always disastrous(mean around 30 out of 100).For my experience,I learn this course all from Youtube by watching the example and do the practice for drawing Shear,axial and bending moment diagram.

If u are following prof Lambros teaching schedule,u must be under-prepared for the final exam because he taught the most important topic: axial, shear, bending moment diagram exactly 1 week before the final exam and with very little and easy examples.U will find yourself lost and puzzled in the sign convention,how to draw the diagram when u revise the topic. To make the situation even worse, there are no tutorial notes for u to practice on because it was during the study period when prof Lambros just started to introduce this important topic which will appear in future like graduate job interview, future CIVL course
reviews.comment_grading:
â€¼ï¸DO PAY attention that if u are enrolled in Prof Lambros class, attendance for lecture and tutorial is MANDATORY, for each lecture skipped ,5% of the total course score will be deducted* and u will F definitely.Don't try to skip the lecture.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is heavy if u want a good grade

5 assignments for this semester,u can check with ur friends

The midterm exam is also manageable (mainly test on Cross product to find moment in 3D plane.......)

But for the final,u should study axial, shear, and bending moment diagram ahead so that u will be well-prepared for the final exam.(that's my study schedule back then)

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: Civil engineering core courses are of good quality. By my By.
reviews.comment_content:
Basic vector stuff.
Stability.
Truss.
Mohr's circle.
NVM analysis.
Pretty rich. Professor added two more lectures to let us do well in the finals. It turned out that the last two lectures are really important because there is a problem taking up 40 marks of the paper about the content of the last two courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is pretty nice. The TAs are really nice too. I have never thought that the teaching quality in Civil and Environmental Engineering can be this high. I had a good experience because of the nice professor and TAs. (Hope my final grade is good as well.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Will update if it comes out.
It is easy to do well in this course as long as you pay attention to every example in the lectures and cram for a night before the exams.
However, the grading is not transparent, which is a little bit of disappointing.
I got 2.5 SD above mean in midterm, did all the questions in the final (don't know which of them are right or wrong. ), and got an A in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload only comes from the 5 assignments and the attendance. (your final overall score would be deducted 5% if you miss the polls in classes. )
You don't really need to review that much as long as you have a pretty solid foundation of high school physics and do the assignments all by yourself before turning to anybody else/sources for help.
